Graphical abstract The kinetic studies of hydroformylation of 1-butene to produce pentanal were investigated by using Rh/PPh3 complex as homogeneous catalyst, valeraldehyde and its polycondensates as solvent. The experiment was carried out on small hydroformylation continuous reaction installation. The effects of reaction temperature, the concentration of 1-butene, the partial pressure of CO or H2 and the concentration of rhodium of catalyst on the reaction rate were studied. Based on the reaction mechanism of hydroformylation and the latest research results of hydroformylation kinetics, the kinetic equation suitable for the hydroformylation of 1-butene was established. The parameters of the kinetic equation were regressed and verified with the experimental data. The relationship between the normal/isomeric ratio of pentanal and the partial pressure of CO was further explored. Keywords Valeraldehyde synthesis Hydroformylation 1-butene Kinetics 1 Introduction In laboratory research and the actual chemical production, the hydroformylation of olefins was widely used. By this reaction, it is possible to obtain the aldehyde as raw materials required for the industry and further get the corresponding alcohols, acids and esters for the production of perfumes, plasticizers, solvents and surfactants. This reaction process generally refers to the olefin reacting with hydrogen and carbon monoxide under the action of a homogeneous catalyst and producing aldehydes as the main product in a certain pressure and temperature. The hydroformylation of 1-butene is an atomic economic reaction to synthesize valeraldehyde. The reaction is as shown below: (Fig. 1 ) The valeraldehyde is an important organic chemical raw material. It could be hydrogenated and oxidized to obtain pentanol and pentanoic acid respectively, which are also important fine chemicals. Methyl dihydrojasmonate, which is synthesized from valeraldehyde, is an excellent substitute for natural jasmine oil. 2-Propyl heptanol produced from valeraldehyde condensed and hydrogenated is a good raw material as a new generation of plasticizer [1]. Phthalic acid isodecyl ester (DPHP) is synthesized through the esterification of 2-propyl heptanol and phthalic acid, which is an excellent substitute for dioctyl phthalate (DOP) and is superior to the traditional DOP in terms of plasticity and environmental friendliness. The production processes of valeraldehyde mainly include dichromate oxidation method, bionic synthesis method, and butene hydroformylation synthesis method. Dichromate oxidation and bionic synthesis had not been industrialized due to various objective conditions. However, a large number of butene could be produced with the oil industry growing prosperous and the corresponding catalyst was found, butene hydroformylation method realized industrial production. According to the different catalyst selected, butene hydroformylation method mainly divided into two ways: the reaction in high pressure with cobalt as catalyst and the reaction in low pressure with rhodium/phosphine as catalyst. Slaugh [2] proposed a cobalt carbonyl complex which has catalytic properties for the hydroformylation which are considerably different from those of dicobalt octacarbonyl. Because the hydroformylation with rhodium carbonyl phosphine complex as catalyst could be carried out under more mild conditions and the rhodium carbonyl phosphine complex possesses good performance, it had been developed and applied commonly in industrial production. In the 1980s, Davy McKee Company [3] developed a production process for the synthesis of valeraldehyde by the hydroformylation of butene with a rhodium complex as catalyst. Then, in order to reduce the cost of separating 1-butene from mixed butene, a new hydroformylation process was exploited. It was called mixed butene two-stage method in low pressure which directly used mixed butene as raw material and rhodium catalyst with bis-phosphite ligand. For example, the double-kettle independent cycle process was proposed by Billing et al. [4] and the double-kettle process of butene hydroformylation with two different catalyst systems was developed by Hoechst Company [5]. In addition, in 1984, Ruhr Chemical Company cooperated with Rhone-Planck Company [6] to develop the hydroformylation process with a water-soluble sulfonated triphenylphosphine- rhodium as a catalyst. This catalyst has a good water solubility, which makes the separation of catalyst and product become a two-phase separation process, and the energy consumption of the separation of product and catalyst is greatly reduced. But the reactivity of the two-phase process is low, and the water-soluble catalyst has poor stability and other aspects of the problems. So the homogeneous catalytic process is still the main process in current industrial production. Since the hydroformylation process was discovered, the kinetics of the hydroformylation process had been deeply researched due to the need for industrial applications. A large number of literatures indicated that the reaction rate of the hydroformylation was positively correlated with the concentration of the catalyst, the concentration of olefins, the partial pressure of hydrogen, and there was an optimal value in the relationship between the reaction rate and the ligand concentration or the partial pressure of carbon monoxide. The reaction rate was maximized at the optimum value, and the reaction rate would slow down when ligand concentration or the partial pressure of carbon monoxide deviated from the optimum value. This also indicates the reaction mechanism of the hydroformylation to some extent. Wilkinson [7–11] had done a lot of researches on the hydroformylation catalyzed by rhodium-phosphine complex and proposed two different paths: a dissociative one and an associative one. Dissociative one is divided to the dissociation of triphenylphosphine (the concentration of triphenylphosphine is low) and the dissociation of carbonyl (the concentration of carbonyl is low). Deshpande [12] and Diwakar [13] had studied the mechanism of hydroformylation of 1-hexene under the catalysis of HRh(CO)(PPh3)3 and proposed reaction mechanism. According to computational results, some studies clarified the mechanism of olefin hydroformylation catalyzed by rhodium complex. Morokuma [14] proposed the potential energy profile for the full cycle of olefin hydroformylation catalyzed by RhH(CO)2(PH3)2, consisting of olefin coordination and insertion, CO insertion, H2 oxidative addition, and aldehyde reductive elimination, as well as ligand coordination and dissociation, which is investigated using the ab initio molecular orbital method. Cundari [15] explored the potential energy hypersurface for ethylene hydroformylation catalyzed by HRh(PH3)2(CO) and made a point that combining the results obtained for each elementary step there are a number of possible pathways for the hydroformylation catalytic cycle, originating from the trans and cis isomers of the active catalyst. Hutter [16] examined an unmodified hydridorhodium carbonyl system together with three variants modified by the model phosphane ligands PF3, PH3 and PMe3, which showed increasing basicity on the Tolman χ parameter scale. In his study, based on the dissociative hydroformylation mechanism, static and dynamic quantum-mechanical approaches were made for preequilibria and the whole catalytic cycle. Jáuregui-Haza [17] first measured the solubility data of hydrogen, carbon monoxide in water, toluene, octene, nonyl alcohol, respectively, and then the kinetics of inhomogeneous hydroformylation of octylene was studied with the sulfonated triphenylphosphine carbonyl rhodium as catalyst and the following empirical equation was obtained: (1) R 0 = k C H 2 C C O C C A T C O C T ( 1 + K A C H 2 ) I ( 1 + K B C C O ) m ( 1 + K D C O T C ) n K, KA, KB, KD are temperature-dependent constants; CCO, C H 2 are the concentrations of carbon monoxide and hydrogen, respectively, kmol/m3; CCAT is the catalyst concentration, and COCT is olefin concentration, kmol/m3. Bernas [18] studied the kinetics of hydroformylation of propylene in a semi-continuous reaction apparatus, by using a mixture of 2,2,4-trimethyl-1, 3-pentanediol monoisobutyrate and valeraldehyde as solvent and using rhodium/cyclohexyl diphenylphosphine (Rh/CHDDP) and rhodium/triphenylphosphine (Rh/PPh3) as catalysts, respectively. The reaction rate of n-butyraldehyde and isobutyraldehyde is as follows: (2) r 1 = dC i d t = k 1 C A C H 2 C CO [ Rh ] [ L ] -m5 ,k 1 = A 1 exp [ − Ea R gas ( 1 T − 1 T mean ) ] (3) r 1 = dC n d t = k 2 C A C H 2 C CO [ Rh ] [ L ] -n5 , k 2 = A 2 exp [ − Ea R gas ( 1 T − 1 T mean ) ] n5, m5, A1, A2 and Ea are parameters; Ci is isobutyraldehyde concentration; Cn is n-butyraldehyde concentration; CA is olefin concentration. Murzin [19] also used HRhCO(PPh3)3 as catalyst to study the mechanism of hydroformylation of propylene based on the work of Bernas et al., taken into account the three existing forms of catalyst in the reaction solution, and considered the balance of functions between them, and finally got the rate equation as follows: (4) r i = kC p C H 2 C CO 1 + aC L + bC L 2 C Rh 0 , r n = kC P C H 2 C CO ( 1 + kC L ) 1 + aC L + bC L 2 C Rh 0 a, b, k are parameters; CP, C H 2 , CCO, CL, CRh are the concentrations of propylene, hydrogen, carbon monoxide, triphenylphosphine and rhodium, respectively. In this paper, the hydroformylation of 1-butene was carried out on the small continuous hydroformylation installation by using Rh/PPh3 complex as homogeneous catalyst, valeraldehyde and its polycondensates as solvent. The process of synthesis of valeraldehyde was studied experimentally. First, the reaction temperature, the concentration of 1-butene, the partial pressure of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, the concentration of rhodium of catalyst were investigated through multi-batch repeated experiments to explore the effect on reaction rate. Fundamental kinetic data were achieved through the experiments. According to the mechanism of hydroformylation and the latest kinetics research results of hydroformylation, the exponential kinetic model was constructed through combining the characteristics of hydroformylation of 1-butene and the data analysis of the experimental results. The kinetic equation of the hydroformylation of 1-butene was obtained by using MATLAB software [20] to regress and verify the parameters in the model. The effects of carbon monoxide partial pressure on the normal/isomeric ratio of the product were further explored, and the empirical equation of normal/isomeric ratio was obtained by the same calculation method. Kinetic basis data and kinetic equation provided in this work can be used for the design of the process and reactor of hydroformylation of 1-butene to synthesize valeraldehyde with Rh/PPh3 as homogeneous catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 1-Butene (≥99% (wt)) was obtained from Qilu Petrochemicals Rubber Factory of Sinopec. Valeraldehyde (≥99% (wt)) as solvent was obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Company. Rh(C5H7O2)(CO)(PPh3) (≥99% (wt)) as catalyst and triphenylphosphine (≥99.0% (wt)) as catalyst ligand were obtained from Hangzhou Kaida Metal Catalyst & Compounds Company. CO and H2 (≥99.9%) were obtained from Tianjin Liufang Industrial Gas Distribution Limited Company. 2.2 Instruments in laboratory The hydroformylation of 1-butene was carried out in a 1L jacketed kettle-reactor which has a magnetic stirrer and a cooling coil. The reactor is heated with hot oil and cooled with tap water. As valeraldehyde could be easily oxidized to valeric acid, the reactor and relative equipment have corrosivity, and the experimental device is made with 316L stainless steel to improve corrosion resistance. The complete hydroformylation installation was designed by Tianjin University R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology, and built by Meryer (Shanghai) Experimental Equipment Co., Ltd. The process chart of the installation is shown in Fig. 2 . The feed flowrate of catalyst and 1-butene was controlled by plunger metering pump respectively, and the feed volumetric flowrate of H2 and CO was regulated through a mass flow meter. The contents of H2 and CO in the exhaust gas were monitored by an on-line analyzer. Butene and butane in the exhaust gas were analyzed by gas chromatography. The pressure of the reaction system was established and controlled by adjusting the exhaust emissions through the gas back pressure valve. The gas and liquid materials in the reactor were taken out together through the reactor overflow pipe, and then entered into the gas-liquid separator. The liquid level in the reactor was kept constant, and the liquid level in the gas-liquid separator was controlled by adjusting the output of the liquid product through the regulating valve. From that the continuous input and output in the installation were realized and the hydroformylation process was in stabilization operation. The data acquisition and parameter control of the experimental process was carried through the control program of Centralized Data Acquisition Control System (PLC). The liquid samples from the reactive product were analyzed by Agilent 6820 gas chromatograph. The composition of C4 in the exhaust gas was analyzed by Shimadzu GC-17A gas chromatograph. The H2 and CO analyzer was product of Beijing North sub-Mehake Analytical Instruments Co., Ltd. 2.3 Experimental procedure At the start of the experiment, a certain concentration of the catalyst solution was prepared with the refined valeraldehyde, as well as the ligand of triphenylphosphine and the complex of acetylacetone triphenylphosphine rhodium carbonyl hydride. Then the catalyst solution was diluted with valeraldehyde and added into the reaction kettle as the initial reaction solution. The air in the reaction system was replaced with N2, and the replacement was considered to be qualified when the content of O2 detected in the exhaust emissions is less than 0.5% (volume fraction). When the experiment started, hydrogen and carbon monoxide was added into the reactor in a proportion, and then the reactor was pressurized up. The gas volumetric flowrate was measured and controlled through the gas mass flowmeter. The mixture in the reactor was heated by means of the heating oil from the recycle hot oil system. When the temperature and pressure of the mixture in the reactor reached the setting values for the designated reaction process, the hydrogen, carbon monoxide, 1-butene and catalyst solution was simultaneously added into the reactor. Due to the butene was in liquid phase in feeding process and the lower boiling point of butene in normal pressure, the butene tank was pressurized a little with nitrogen, and the butene feed line was cooled with −15°C glycol cooling solution to prevent the butene feed pump from cavitation. As the catalyst solution contains triphenylphosphine, which is easily crystallized at a lower temperature and leads to the clog of the feed line, the electric heating ribbon is used to insulation and heat tracing in the catalyst tank and the catalyst feed line. As the reaction proceeded, the reaction pressure was maintained constant by adjusting the back pressure valve on the reactor exhaust line, and the temperature of the circulating hot oil was adjusted to maintain the reaction temperature constant. At the same time, the speed of stirring blade of the reactor was set to the appropriate value in order to realize uniform mixing of the reaction material in the reactor. When the reaction carried continuously for a period of time, the composition and flow rate of the exhaust gas, the composition of the product and the flow rate of input and output were relatively stable, the reaction process was considered to be in relative stability state. At this time, the gas sample was taken from the reaction exhaust gas by means of a gas sampling bag. The sample of the liquid product was taken from the product output line with a sampler and the samples of gas and liquid product were analyzed by gas chromatography. After the experimental process was in basically stable state, the samples were taken at interval about two hours. If the analysis data of two adjacent samples had good repeatability, it indicated that the experimental process had reached a real steady-state. At this moment, the corresponding experimental data, for example, process operating parameters and corresponding analytical data were collected under the setting experimental conditions. After obtaining the experimental data under steady-state conditions, the experimental process can be stopped. The samples of liquid product, which contained the volatile components of butene and pentanal, needed to be stored in a frozen state and sent to the gas chromatographic analysis to prevent the analysis data from being not accurate due to volatilization of components. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Experimental data processing and analysis The more complete and reliable experimental data can be gotten through the data acquisition function of PLC system and gas chromatography analysis. The effects of reaction temperature, the concentration of rhodium of catalyst, the concentration of 1-butene, and the partial pressure of hydrogen or carbon monoxide on reaction rate were investigated systematically. The experimental results of different batches can be obtained through analyzing and processing a lot of test data. The reaction rate was represented by the 1-butene consumption rate and was calculated on the measured liquid volume of the reaction mixture and material balance. The molar ratio of n-valeraldehyde to 2-methyl butyraldehyde was obtained from the analytical composition of the liquid products. However, considering the limitation of process conditions of hydroformylation of 1-butene in the laboratory, there are not larger numbers of batches carried out, and the experimental conditions set more fit the actual production. The experimental results of 24 batches are obtained through the records and processing of experimental data. The effects of reaction temperature, the concentration of rhodium of catalyst, the concentration of 1-butene, and the partial pressure of hydrogen or carbon monoxide on reaction rate were studied through the experimental data of different batches. In designated experimental process condition, the investigating parameter was considered change and the other parameters were relatively stable. The effect of CO partial pressure on the normal/isomeric ratio of the reaction product was also discussed. 3.1.1 The effect of temperature on the reaction rate From Table 1 , the data of batch 11 to batch 14 were selected to study the effect of the reaction temperature on the reaction rate of 1-butene. The results are shown in Fig. 3 . It can be seen from Fig. 3 that the reaction rate increases with the increase of the reaction temperature. When the reaction temperature exceeds 100°C, the increases of the reaction rate slows down with the reaction temperature increases. When the reaction temperature reaches about 120°C, the amounts of butane formed by hydrogenation of 1-butene and pentanol formed by hydrogenation of valeraldehyde increase in the results of chromatographic analysis. When the reaction temperature is 100–120°C, the reaction rate of 1-butene is gradually increased, but the increase rate is gradually decreased, and the selectivity of 1-butene reaction to valeraldehyde is reduced. Therefore, the maximum reaction temperature of this kinetic experiment would not exceed 120°C. 3.1.2 The effect of the concentration of rhodium catalyst on the reaction rate From Table 2 , the data of batch 7 to batch 10 were selected to study the concentration of rhodium catalyst on the 1-butene reaction rate. The reaction results are shown in Fig. 4 . As seen from Fig. 4, the reaction rate increases with the concentration of rhodium catalyst increases. While the concentration of rhodium catalyst is between 150 and 250ppm, the reaction rate increases faster with the increase of the concentration of rhodium catalyst. While the concentration of rhodium catalyst exceeds 250ppm, the reaction rate increases slowly. Although the concentration of rhodium catalyst is high, there is no increase in side reaction products through chromatographic analysis to reaction products. It is better consideration that the amount of catalyst is minimized to reduce the cost while a faster reaction rate is still maintained. Therefore, the concentration of rhodium catalyst of 250ppm is more appropriate. 3.1.3 The effect of the concentration of 1-butene on the reaction rate From Table 3 , the data of batch 1, batch 4, batch 16 and batch 24 were selected to study the concentration of 1-butene on the reaction rate. The reaction results are shown in Fig. 4. As seen from Fig. 5 , the reaction rate increases with the concentration of 1-butene increases. 1-Butene, as the most important reactant involved in the hydroformylation, takes part in the vast majority of links, so the effect of its concentration on the reaction rate is more obvious. The rise of reaction rate is nearly linear with the increase of the concentration of 1-butene. 3.1.4 The effect of the partial pressure of hydrogen on the reaction rate There are two important gases in the hydroformylation, hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which are the gas reactant and influence the reaction pressure. The effect of the partial pressure of hydrogen and carbon monoxide on the reaction was investigated respectively. The data of batch 16, batch 17, batch 21 and batch23 were selected from Table 4 to study the effect of the partial pressure of hydrogen on the reaction rate. The reaction results are shown in Fig. 6 . As seen from Fig. 6, the reaction rate is in a narrow range with the increase of the partial pressure of H2, while the partial pressure of H2 is in the range of 0.98–1.99MPa. Due to the gas analyzer has a limitation that the gas flowrate should not be less than a certain value (0.5NL/min) to ensure the gas analyzer can be in working order, the feed amount of H2 is more than that needed in the experiment process, and the partial pressure of H2 is in a high range all the time. The effect of the partial pressure of H2 on the reaction rate is mainly manifested in gas mass transfer and the step of H2 oxidative addition. While the partial pressure of H2 is high enough, the H2 mass transfer rate is large enough that the reaction rate is no longer affected by the H2 mass transfer rate and the concentration of H2 in reaction liquid is also large enough that it has little effect in the step of H2 oxidative addition. 3.1.5 The effect of the partial pressure of carbon monoxide on the reaction rate Then, the data of batch 7, batch 18 to batch 20 were selected from Table 5 to study the effect of carbon monoxide partial pressure on the reaction rate. The reaction results are shown in Fig. 7 . It can be seen from Fig. 7 that when the partial pressure of CO is lower than 0.17MPa, the reaction rate increases with the increase of the partial pressure of CO. When the partial pressure of CO is higher than 0.17MPa, the reaction rate is dropped slightly. Of course, it varies within a certain range. The CO play a major role in the hydroformylation as gas reactant and the step of CO coordination/insertion is also the key step of the full cycle of olefin hydroformylation. So the partial pressure of CO has an increasing effect on the reaction rate at first. However, the reaction rate is dropped slightly with the partial pressure of CO increases further. It is possible that a CO coordinates to the acyl complex, competing with the incoming H2. 3.1.6 The effect of the partial pressure of CO on the normal/isomeric ratio of product The n-valeraldehyde can be synthesized through the hydroformylation of 1-butene and part of 2-methyl butyraldehyde will be produced at the same time. The normal/isomeric ratio is defined as the mole ratio of n-valeraldehyde and 2-methyl butyraldehyde in the production. It is also an important performance data of the reaction and has a direct impact on the production capacity and economic benefits. In industrial production, it is more desirable to produce n-valeraldehyde. Therefore, excess triphenylphosphine is added in the catalyst solution in order to increase the concentration of the triphenylphosphine of catalyst ligand in industrial production and reduce the amount of carbonyl ligands in the catalyst complex at the same time. As the role of steric hindrance of the catalyst increases, the normal/isomeric ratio of products increases. In addition to the concentration of triphenylphosphine, the partial pressure of CO is also the main factor affecting the normal/isomeric ratio of pentanal products [3]. The concentration of the triphenylphosphine in the reaction solution is always kept to about 13% (wt%) in the experimental process so that the effect of triphenylphosphine concentration on the normal/isomeric ratio of the products is not investigated. The partial pressure of CO can also affect the distribution of the different structures of the catalyst complex in the reaction solution. With the increase of the partial pressure of CO, the number of carbonyl ligands increases in the catalyst complex, the role of steric hindrance of the catalyst is weakened, and the normal/isomeric ratio decreases. While ensuring the different partial pressure of CO, the data of batch 1 to batch 7, batch 9 to batch 12, batch 16, batch 17 and batch 20 from Table 6 were selected to study the effect of the partial pressure of CO on the normal/isomeric ratio of product. The reaction results are shown in Fig. 8 . As seen from Fig. 8, the normal/isomeric ratio of the pentanal product is gradually reduced with the increase of the partial pressure of CO from the overall trend, which is substantially independent of the reaction temperature, the partial pressure of H2, the concentration of rhodium of catalyst, and the concentration of 1-butene. The normal/isomeric ratios of products are mostly distributed from 7 to 10. When the normal/isomeric ratio of products is 12 or more, the partial pressure of CO is too low and the reaction rate becomes slow. Therefore, the partial pressure of CO should not be too low. 3.2 Kinetic studies 3.2.1 Hydroformylation reaction mechanism In order to construct the kinetic model equation, it is necessary to clarify the mechanism of hydroformylation of Rh/PPh3 as a homogeneous catalyst. The work of Wilkinson [7–11] and Diwakar [13] is referenced. Considering that the concentration of triphenylphosphine in our experimental process is relative high and can be considered as a constant and the partial pressure of CO is relative low resulting in the low concentration of carbonyl, the processes of reaction mechanism of hydroformylation in our experimental process mainly include the process of association and the dissociation of carbonyl. The structure of the catalyst complex in the reaction process is HRh(CO)x(PPh3)y, where x+y=4. First, the catalyst forms an olefin complex RCHCH2 ∼HRh(CO)x(PPh3)y with the olefin, and then the olefin is bonded to the hydrogen in the catalyst to form an alkyl complex RCH2CH2Rh(CO)x(PPh3)y. The migratory insertion of CO into Rh-alkyl bond takes place to form RCH2CH2CORh(CO)x-1(PPh3)y, after hydrogenation it becomes RCH2CH2CHO+HRh(CO)x-1(PPh3)y. Finally, it combines with CO to form HRh(CO)x(PPh3)y, and the catalyst returns to its original state. The different C atom in the olefinic bond combines with the catalyst will result in the final formation of the n-aldehyde or isomeric aldehyde, respectively, when it forms an olefin complex. Since the molecular volume of PPh3 is large, the role of steric hindrance is strong, so the hydroformylation tends to generate n-aldehyde. The active substances in the catalyst of the two processes are HRh(CO)2(PPh3)2 and HRh(CO)(PPh3)2, respectively. The mechanism of the reaction is shown in Fig. 9 . 3.2.2 Kinetic model and parameter regression According to the reactive mechanism of hydroformylation of 1-butene with Rh/PPh3 as homogeneous catalyst and the effect of each factor on the reaction rate in the analysis of experimental results, in order to express the reaction rate of 1-butene better, the empirical equation of the model is expressed by an exponential model. (5) R = exp ( A − B / RT ) P H 2 k 1 P CO k 2 [ Rh ] k 3 [ L ] k 4 [ C 4 ] k 5 Meanwhile, it is considered that the concentration of triphenylphosphine in this experiment is approximately constant and the effect of the partial pressure of CO on the reaction rate first increases and then reduces. The partial pressure of CO has a suitable partial pressure range. So the construction equation is improved as follows. (6) R = Aexp ( B/RT ) P H 2 k 1 P CO k 2 [ Rh ] k 3 [ C 4 ] k 4 exp ( k 5 P CO ) The A, B, k1, k2, k3, k4 and k5 are the parameter to be determined. The T is the reaction temperature. The P H 2 is H2 partial pressure and PCO is CO partial pressure. The [Rh] is the rhodium concentration of catalyst and the [C4] is 1-butene concentration. The [L] is the concentration of triphenylphosphine. Using Matlab2013b calculation software, the linear least squares method and the nonlinear least squares method are used to regress the parameters of the kinetic equation and test its accuracy. First, each sides of Eq. (6) are taken logarithm as below: (7) Y = a 0 + a 1 x 1 + a 2 x 2 + a 3 x 3 + a 4 x 4 + a 5 x 5 + a 6 x 6 In the Eq. (7), a0 =lnA, a1 =B, x1 =1/RT, a2 =k1, x2 =ln P H 2 , a3 =k2, x3 =lnPCO, a4 =k3, x4 =ln[Rh], a5 =k4, x5 =ln[C4], a6 =−k5, x6 =PCO. The data of batch 7 to batch 13 and batch 15 to batch 18 from Table 7 were selected to provide an initial value for the following nonlinear parametric regression by Matlab2013b with function “regress()”.Results can be obtained as follows. a0 =2.97, a1 =0, a2 =0.1421, a3 =0.2066, a4 =−0.1011, a5 =−0.6777, a6 =−1.281. The results of the regression were evaluated. The correlation coefficient r2 is 0.9942. The closer the value of the correlation coefficient is to 1, the more accurate the regression equation parameter value will be. Therefore, the experimental data can be fitted with the equation well. The value of F and p is used to evaluate the effect of fitting in a regression model. The value of F is 171.7945. The greater the value of F is, the more significant the regression will be. The value of p is 0.00001. The smaller of the value of p is, the smaller the error of regression will be. It can be seen from the above data that the results obtained by regression and experimental data fit well, the results have high credibility. The results of the regression were further analyzed. The residuals and its confidence intervals were plotted. The results are shown in Fig. 10 : As seen from Fig. 10, all data contain zero and the error is small, indicating that the experimental data and the data calculated through the kinetic equation have good fitting. The parameter is obtained as the initial value, and according to the previous chart analysis, the data of batch 7 to batch 24 from Table 7 which had a better kinetic regularity were selected to get the final kinetic equation by Matlab2013b with function “nlinfit()”. (8) R = 2 .1302exp ( − 5090 .4168/RT ) P H 2 0 .0481 P CO 0 .0221 [ Rh ] 0 .0855 [ C 4 ] 1 .0027 exp ( 0 .2117P CO ) The experimental rate and the fitting value of the 18 batches of data are shown in Table 8 , where Re represents the experimental value and Rc represents the fitting value. It can be seen from Table 8 that the fitting value is very close to the experimental value. At the same time, the characteristics can be seen from the above reaction rate equations as follows: The kinetic experiment is carried out in the range of high partial pressure of hydrogen. The effect of the partial pressure of H2 on the reaction rate is mainly manifested in gas mass transfer and the step of H2 oxidative addition. While the partial pressure of H2 is high enough, the H2 mass transfer rate is large enough that the reaction rate is no longer affected by the H2 mass transfer rate and the concentration of H2 in reaction liquid is also large enough that it has little effect in the step of H2 oxidative addition. The CO play a major role in the hydroformylation as gas reactant and the step of CO coordination/insertion is also the key step of the full cycle of olefin hydroformylation. So the partial pressure of CO has an increasing effect on the reaction rate at first. However, the reaction rate is dropped slightly with the partial pressure of CO increases further. It is possible that a CO coordinates to the acyl complex, competing with the incoming H2. Combine the both, there is the most suitable partial pressure of CO for the reaction, the reaction rate will decrease whether over or below this partial pressure. 4 The reaction rate increases with the increase of the concentration of rhodium of catalyst, which can also be seen in the mapping analysis 1-butene, as the most important reactant involved in the reaction process, takes part in the vast majority of links, so the effect of its concentration on the reaction rate is more obvious. The higher the concentration of 1-butene is, the faster the reaction rate will be. It can also be seen from the equation that the concentration of 1-butene is of a linear function of the reaction rate, that is, the first order reaction. From Fig. 8, the ratio of n-valeraldehyde to 2-methyl butyraldehyde in the product is changed by the partial pressure of CO. The normal/isomeric ratio of the pentanal product gradually reduces with the increase of the partial pressure of CO from the overall trend. Through the study of other hydroformylation process, especially the kinetic research results of the hydroformylation of propylene synthesized to butyraldehyde, the relationship between the ratio of n-butyraldehyde to isobutyraldehyde and the partial pressure of CO was referred [21].Considering the concentration of triphenylphosphine is approximately constant in this experiment, the following equation can be constructed for parameter regression and verification. (9) R n R i = A 1 + BP CO 1 + CP CO The 14 sets of data in Fig. 8 were selected to obtain the parameters and test by Matlab2013b with function “nlinfit()”. The result is A=22.9385，B=0.4095，C=8.2214. (10) R n R i = 22.9385 1 + 0.4095 P CO 1 + 8.2214 P CO The analysis of the experimental value and regression equations is plotted as follows: It can be seen from Fig. 11 that the experimental values are distributed evenly on both sides of the regression equation curve and have a good fitting. Since the concentration of triphenylphosphine is constant, and the partial pressure of CO has an effect on the reaction rate and n/iso ratio of the product. The partial pressure of CO should be strictly controlled within the appropriate range. 5 Conclusions The kinetic experiment was carried out in the small continuous hydroformylation installation in the laboratory with Rh/PPh3 as the liquid phase homogeneous catalyst and valeraldehyde and its polycondensate as solvent. The experimental data were analyzed and evaluated, and the basic experimental data were provided for the regression of the reaction kinetic equation. The conclusions are as follows. 1. The kinetic experiment has its limitations. The regression equation is constrained by the following conditions: Higher partial pressure of hydrogen was used in the reaction process, and the molar feed ratio of H2 and CO was about 2 for the operational model. Therefore, this experiment was under the conditions of the fully sufficient hydrogen and the higher partial pressure of hydrogen (about 1MPa). It may not be applicable for lower partial pressure of hydrogen. This experiment was carried out under the condition that the mass fraction of triphenylphosphine was about 13% (wt%). The effect of the concentration of triphenylphosphine on the reaction rate was not considered. 2. The effects of reaction temperature, the concentration of 1-butene, the partial pressure of CO or H2 and the concentration of rhodium of catalyst on the reaction rate were investigated and the characteristics of the change of reaction rate were also obtained as Eq. (8). 3. By using the Matlab2013b software, the kinetic equation of hydroformylation of 1-butene to synthesize pentanal and the empirical equation of the relationship between the ratio of n-valeraldehyde to 2-methyl butyraldehyde in the product and the partial pressure of CO was obtained as Eq. (10). 4. Based on the discussion above, the applicable conditions of the kinetic equation are: The range of partial pressure of hydrogen is 0.5∼2.0MPa, the range of partial pressure of CO is 0.05∼0.35MPa, the range of total reaction pressure is 1.0∼2.5MPa, the concentration of rhodium of catalyst in reaction solution is 150∼350ppm, the reaction temperature is 90∼120°C, the mass fraction of triphenylphosphine is about 13wt%, the concentration of 1-butene is 2.5∼5.0mol/L. The basic research of the above kinetic experiments lays a good foundation for an accurate description of hydroformylation of 1-butene to prepare valeraldehyde reaction process, optimizes the reaction conditions, and improves the design of the reactor. Thus, a better theoretical foundation is established for the development of the core technology and equipment of the industrial production. References [1] R.R. Kozlowski U. coredata.dc:description: The kinetic studies of hydroformylation of 1-butene to produce pentanal were investigated by using Rh/PPh3 complex as homogeneous catalyst, valeraldehyde and its polycondensates as solvent. The experiment was carried out on small hydroformylation continuous reaction installation. The effects of reaction temperature, the concentration of 1-butene, the partial pressure of CO or H2 and the concentration of rhodium of catalyst on the reaction rate were studied. Based on the reaction mechanism of hydroformylation and the latest research results of hydroformylation kinetics, the kinetic equation suitable for the hydroformylation of 1-butene was established. The parameters of the kinetic equation were regressed and verified with the experimental data. The relationship between the normal/isomeric ratio of pentanal and the partial pressure of CO was further explored.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetic studies of hydroformylation of 1-butene using homogeneous Rh/PPh3 complex catalyst
